question.title: How to map a specific value for each object in list without custom mapper and @AfterMapping
question.body:
Say I have these classes:

public class Source {
    private LocalDate date;
    private List<String> entries;
}

public class Target {
    private Long id;
    private LocalDate date;
    private List<String> entries;
}

I want to create a map like this:

List<Target> sourceToTarget(Long id, List<Source> source);

Is there any way to do this without a custom mapper or the @AfterMapping annotation? I have tried this as well:

@Mapping(target = "id", source = "id")
List<Target> sourceToTarget(Long id, List<Source> source);

This doesn't work.

answers.body:
It doesn't seems that you can take additionnal parameters when mapping to a List.
I would use the following method for mapping :

@Mapping(target = "id", source = "id")
Target sourceToTarget(Long id, Source source);

And then you can use a stream().map() to collect to your final list.
You don't loose much.

there is a workaround that still uses MapStruct but avoids @AfterMapping or a full custom mapper implementation.

    @Mapping(target = "id", expression = "java(context.getId())")
    Target sourceToTarget(Source source, @Context IdContext context);

79623383.body: You can change type of context to Long and avoid creating wrapper class. Access it by expression = "java(context)"
